lens.book_chapters: All chapters: Usability Laws and Design Principles

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements restructure the listing evaluation to lead with human-compatibility signals instead of property data. guest-looks-006 (Schedule Compatibility Indicator) makes the day-of-week schedule pattern the first visual signal on listing cards. rb-ui-001 (People-First Listing Hero) extends this same philosophy to the full listing detail page, leading with host profile, schedule pattern, lifestyle details, and guest testimonial before property photos and price.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman/Nneka): The guest's System 1 needs a familiar pattern to assess compatibility in a single glance -- schedule badges as the first visual signal on cards. Outside-in (Krug/SpareRoom): Five independent transcripts confirm users' primary concerns are human factors (who shares, cleaning, daily routine) which are invisible on every listing page in the category. Valerie: 'I feel like I'm moving every single week' -- her concerns were about human reality, not property specs. Both processes arrive at the same conclusion from different directions: lead with people, not property.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: This is a CROSS-PROCESS REINFORCEMENT. The design-stack (Kahneman lens on Nneka's call) independently identified schedule-first listing cards as a System 1 need. The reverse-benchmark (Krug lens on SpareRoom) independently identified people-first listing hierarchy as the core category gap. Together they validate a complete information architecture: schedule compatibility on search cards (guest-looks-006), human-first hierarchy on listing detail pages (rb-ui-001). The signal is strongest when two different theoretical frameworks analyzing two different data sources produce the same design direction.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address the post-contact commitment pipeline. guest-communicates-005 (Proposal Progress Pipeline) shows the guest where they are, what happens next, and who acts at each stage. rb-ui-002 (Scaffolded First Contact Card) addresses the specific moment BEFORE the pipeline begins -- the terrifying blank-message-box moment of first contact with a stranger.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman/Nneka): The proposal pipeline needs to resolve uncertainty at every moment because unresolved ambiguity forces continuous System 2 monitoring that depletes the guest. Outside-in (Krug/SpareRoom): Every guest transcript begins with cascading questions the platform cannot answer. Vince: 'I've never done something like this.' Tamycka: 'how does that process work?' The phone call serves as the structured template that the blank message box fails to provide. Both processes confirm that the commitment path needs structure at every step -- the DS elements cover the middle and end, while the RB element fills the critical beginning.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: CROSS-PROCESS REINFORCEMENT. The design-stack identified the pipeline middle (proposal stages, action assignment, timeframes) through System 2 uncertainty analysis. The reverse-benchmark identified the pipeline beginning (first contact scaffolding) through usability analysis of the blank-message-box failure. Together they complete the full guided commitment path from first contact through move-in.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements provide navigation and status visibility for the commitment journey. guest-behaves-004 (Proposal Pipeline as Anxiety-Resolving Status Stream) transforms the pipeline into a status stream that resolves uncertainty. rb-ui-003 (Commitment Journey Breadcrumb) creates a persistent horizontal breadcrumb bar showing the complete path from Introduction to Move-In with clear indicators of who acts next.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman): Unresolved uncertainty forces continuous System 2 monitoring -- the guest cannot stop thinking about the proposal. Status visibility frees System 2. Outside-in (Krug Chapter 6): Street Signs and Breadcrumbs establish that users need to know where they are, where they've been, and where they can go. SpareRoom provides absolutely zero navigation for the post-contact journey. Both processes independently prescribe making every step visible and navigable, with clear assignment of who acts next.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: CROSS-PROCESS REINFORCEMENT. The design-stack's anxiety-resolving status stream and the reverse-benchmark's commitment breadcrumb are different visual expressions of the same principle: make the invisible commitment journey visible and navigable. The Krug breadcrumb pattern adds a persistent navigation bar; the Kahneman status stream adds emotional resolution through timeframe expectations. Merging produces a breadcrumb-style navigation that also resolves anxiety through action assignment and time estimates.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address the active-stay management phase. guest-works-003 (Stays Manager as System 1 Weekly Dashboard) designs the core weekly-visit experience as a hero card that answers 'what do I need to do right now?' in a 3-second glance. rb-ui-004 (Host Turnover Checklist) designs the host-side operational tooling within the same Stays Manager -- a smart digital checklist that remembers the host's protocol and surfaces guest feedback.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman/Nneka): The weekly Stays Manager visit competes with work preparation for System 2 resources; the interaction must complete in a single glance. Outside-in (Krug/SpareRoom): Chantel built an entire manual system (physical book with inventory checklists, building access, cleaning protocols) because no platform supports the turnover process. Both processes confirm that the Stays Manager is the foundational architecture for active-stay management -- the DS addresses the guest side, the RB fills the critical host-side gap.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: CROSS-PROCESS REINFORCEMENT. This is the STRONGEST convergence signal in the entire library. Four independent runs (Kahneman, Eyal, Christensen, and now Krug) all identify the Stays Manager / active-stay management as foundational architecture. The design-stack built the guest-side dashboard; the reverse-benchmark now fills the host-side operational gap that Chantel's manual inventory book revealed. This element extends the Stays Manager from a guest tool into a bilateral platform for both sides of the living arrangement.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address the review and reputation system. guest-communicates-007 (Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points) designs when reviews are prompted. rb-ui-005 (Portable Reputation Timeline) designs how accumulated reviews are displayed -- as a chronological narrative across leases that both hosts and guests carry forward.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman): Batched review prompts at Week 4, midpoint, and final reduce cognitive burden while capturing higher-quality feedback. Outside-in (Krug/SpareRoom): SpareRoom's hidden references feature is functionally invisible and never prompted. Cristina: 'I don't remember if his deposit isn't I, you know' -- hosts rely on failing memory. Both processes confirm that (a) reviews must be prompted at natural moments, and (b) they must accumulate into a visible, portable narrative. The DS handles the collection mechanism; the RB handles the display and portability.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: CROSS-PROCESS REINFORCEMENT. The design-stack (Eyal/Kahneman) designed the review capture cadence. The Booking.com reverse-benchmark designed the micro-review pulse and timeline visualization. Now the SpareRoom reverse-benchmark independently identifies the same gap (hidden review system, memory failure) and designs the portable reputation timeline that makes the accumulated reviews useful across leases. Three independent processes converging on the same architecture.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address review visualization. The existing rb-ui-002 (Stay-Cycle Review Timeline, from the Booking.com run) visualizes weekly micro-review pulses as a horizontal timeline within a single lease. The new rb-ui-005 (Portable Reputation Timeline) extends this to a cross-lease chronological narrative that accumulates across multiple leases and hosts.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Booking.com RB (Eyal/Hook Model): The stay-cycle review timeline provides Variable Reward by showing the guest their contribution growing week by week within a single lease. SpareRoom RB (Krug): The portable reputation timeline solves the cross-lease identity problem -- no platform builds portable flatmate reputation. The Booking.com element handles within-lease visualization; the SpareRoom element handles cross-lease accumulation. Together they form a complete reputation architecture: micro-reviews within each lease (rb-ui-002/Booking.com), accumulating into a portable narrative across leases (rb-ui-005/SpareRoom).
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Two independent reverse-benchmark runs (different competitors, different books) converge on the same temporal review architecture. The Booking.com run provided the micro-review pulse and within-lease timeline. The SpareRoom run provides the cross-lease reputation timeline. This is a reverse-benchmark-to-reverse-benchmark reinforcement that validates the review timeline as a category-defining feature.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address concept comprehension and self-evidence at the discovery phase. works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition) prescribes that each new context must signal continuity and pass System 1 assessment within 2 seconds. rb-ui-006 (How Split Lease Works) makes the entire Split Lease concept self-evident in a 5-second scannable three-step visual for cold-traffic users who have never spoken to anyone.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman/Andreas): The System 1 trust gate ensures returning users see continuity at every transition. Outside-in (Krug/SpareRoom): Every guest transcript begins with 'how does this work?' because the platform cannot answer its own most basic question. The DS element handles warm-traffic users who have spoken to an agent; the RB element handles cold-traffic users arriving without a phone call -- filling the critical discovery gap.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The design-stack identified the trust gate for warm-traffic (post-call) users. The reverse-benchmark identified the self-evidence gap for cold-traffic (pre-call) users. Together they ensure concept comprehension across both acquisition channels.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address emotional design. feels-008 (The Human Thread: The Host Should Always Feel One Step from a Real Person) ensures the host always has access to human support. rb-ui-007 (Emotional Milestone Toast) celebrates real milestones and provides reassurance at anxiety peaks for both hosts and guests.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman): Associative warmth -- every touchpoint must emotionally rhyme with the phone call. The Human Thread ensures a human is always reachable. Outside-in (Krug Ch 10): The Reservoir of Goodwill concept shows that emotional acknowledgment is a usability imperative. Every transcript overflows with anxiety ('I feel like it would be a lot of work'), vulnerability ('I've never done something like this'), and fear ('I have to make sure everything is legit') that no platform acknowledges. The DS element provides the human safety net; the RB element provides the emotional celebration and reassurance system.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The design-stack identified the need for human accessibility (safety net). The reverse-benchmark identified the need for proactive emotional acknowledgment (celebration and reassurance). Together they form a complete emotional design system: a human thread for when things go wrong, and milestone toasts for when things go right.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements transform blank-field composition into structured, guided interactions. communicates-005 (Pre-Packaged Proposal: Present Decisions as Confirmations, Not Constructions) structures the host-side proposal acceptance. rb-ui-002 (Scaffolded First Contact Card) structures the guest-side initial outreach.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman/Andreas): The host should confirm, not construct -- proposals arrive pre-packaged with the guest's information organized for quick review. Outside-in (Krug/SpareRoom): The guest faces a blank message box at peak social anxiety; structured chips and templates transform this into a fill-in-the-blanks exercise. Both processes prescribe the same principle from opposite sides of the marketplace: eliminate blank-field composition at high-stakes moments.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Inside-out and outside-in processes converge on the same interaction principle (structured confirmation over blank-field construction) applied to opposite sides of the marketplace. This validates the principle as universal across user roles.

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address the off-platform workaround problem in active stays. guest-works-004 (Eliminate Off-Platform Communication) makes the platform faster than texting for schedule changes. rb-ui-004 (Host Turnover Checklist) digitizes the manual physical systems hosts build because no platform supports the turnover process.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out (Kahneman/Nneka): Brad texts Nneka to reschedule because the platform has no equivalent fast path. The platform must compete on speed with text messaging. Outside-in (Krug/SpareRoom): Chantel maintains a physical book with checklists because no platform supports active-stay operations. Both reveal the same underlying failure: platforms exit the relationship at move-in, forcing both sides to build manual workarounds (texting for guests, physical checklists for hosts).
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The design-stack identified the guest-side off-platform communication workaround (texting). The reverse-benchmark identified the host-side off-platform operational workaround (physical checklists). Together they reveal a bilateral active-stay management gap that the Stays Manager must fill from both sides.

contradictions.conflict: The new rb-ui-001 (People-First Listing Hero) uses Inter and DM Sans fonts with a purple palette (#31135D, rgb(109,49,194), rgb(140,104,238)). The existing looks-005 (Green Trust Badges) reserves the accent color exclusively for verified and guaranteed elements, using the green accent (#2d5a3d) from tokens.json. The new element uses purple for trust-adjacent signals like the compatibility tag, which could create confusion with verified/guaranteed badges if both appear on the same listing page.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The production CSS (Style-guide.md) uses the purple palette, which the new elements correctly follow. However, tokens.json still specifies green (#2d5a3d) for accent trust signals. This is a known drift (documented in MEMORY.md). The rb-ui-001 compatibility tag ('Your weekday pattern aligns') is not a verification badge but could be visually confused with one if placed near green trust badges.
contradictions.recommendation: Establish a clear visual distinction: green trust badges (#2d5a3d or equivalent in production) for platform-verified facts (ID verified, credit checked), purple accent badges for compatibility signals (schedule alignment, lifestyle match). The Vetting Trust Shield (rb-ui-003 from Booking.com run) already follows this pattern correctly. Flag the compatibility tag in rb-ui-001 for visual differentiation from trust badges.

extensions.gap_filled: Listing detail page information architecture. The library has strong elements for search-card scanning (guest-looks-006, Schedule Compatibility Indicator) but no element restructures the listing detail page to lead with human compatibility signals. This is a new level of the information hierarchy: cards lead with schedule pattern, detail pages lead with host profile, lifestyle, and testimonials.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong confidence. Five independent user transcripts validate that human factors are the primary decision driver. Krug's visual hierarchy principle directly supports people-first design. However, the element is from reverse-benchmark (competitor analysis) rather than direct user testing, so implementation should be validated with user research on information hierarchy preferences.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes -- a design-stack run using listing evaluation transcripts (Valerie, Vince, William) should validate whether the specific hierarchy (host profile > schedule > testimonial > photos > price) matches actual guest scanning behavior.

extensions.gap_filled: First-contact moment scaffolding. The library has the proposal pipeline middle (guest-communicates-005) and proposal presentation for hosts (communicates-005), but no element addresses the terrifying first-contact moment when a guest decides to reach out. This fills the beginning of the commitment path.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong confidence. Krug's mindless-choices principle is directly applicable: three structured sections (About You, Why This Listing, Your Dates) transform a thinking-heavy moment into a fill-in-the-blanks exercise. Every guest transcript includes the pattern of calling a phone number because the messaging provides no scaffolding.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes -- test with guest transcripts whether the structured template captures the information hosts actually care about. Chantel's call reveals she always asks 'what are you coming here for?' which maps to the Why This Listing chips.

extensions.gap_filled: Host-side active-stay management tooling. The library has 7+ guest-side Stays Manager elements but no host-side operational tools. Chantel's manual inventory book is the strongest gap signal: a real user building an elaborate workaround for a missing platform feature.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong confidence. Chantel's transcript provides direct evidence of the manual workaround. The turnover checklist is a digitization of an existing user behavior, which is the highest-confidence design pattern (making existing behavior easier rather than inventing new behavior).
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Moderate -- the checklist should be validated with multiple hosts to confirm that Chantel's protocol is representative. A host-focused design-stack run using Chantel, Cristina, and Nneka transcripts would validate the specific checklist items and workflow.

extensions.gap_filled: Portable cross-lease reputation. The library has review capture mechanisms (guest-communicates-007, rb-ui-001/Booking.com micro-review pulse) and within-lease visualization (rb-ui-002/Booking.com review timeline), but no element designs how review data accumulates into a cross-lease narrative that returning users carry forward.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. The concept is theoretically sound (Cristina cannot remember past guests, SpareRoom's references are hidden), but the portable reputation timeline is a novel concept with no direct user request. Users express the pain (memory failure, starting from zero) but have not articulated the solution (temporal narrative). Implementation should start with the within-lease timeline and evolve to cross-lease only after sufficient data accumulates.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes -- critical validation needed. No transcript explicitly asks for a cross-lease reputation timeline. The evidence is inference from pain (Cristina's memory failure, SpareRoom's hidden references) rather than explicit demand. A focused design-stack run with returning guests/hosts would validate whether the reputation timeline affects trust decisions.

extensions.gap_filled: Cold-traffic concept comprehension. The library addresses post-call trust bridges (works-004) and phone-call speed matching (works-003) but has no element for users who arrive at the platform without a phone call. Every guest transcript begins with 'how does this work?' -- this element answers that question visually in 5 seconds.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong confidence. The evidence is overwhelming: every guest transcript includes concept confusion. Krug's self-evidence principle provides the theoretical mandate. The three-step visual (share a schedule, propose dates, manage stays) maps directly to the actual platform flow.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Moderate -- the concept is validated by transcript evidence but the specific visual (split-week calendar, proposal icon, stays house icon) should be tested for comprehension speed. A/B test the explainer section against a text-based version to confirm that visual > verbal for concept transmission.

extensions.gap_filled: Proactive emotional acknowledgment across the guest journey. The library has The Human Thread (feels-008) for reactive human accessibility and Forward Momentum (feels-006) for closing interactions, but no element designs proactive emotional celebration at milestones (proposal accepted, first stay completed, positive review received).
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. Every transcript overflows with emotional language, and Krug's Reservoir of Goodwill concept provides theoretical support. However, emotional design is inherently harder to validate through competitor analysis. The risk is that milestone toasts feel patronizing to experienced users -- the progressive intensity design (heavy for first-timers, light for returning users) mitigates this but needs real-world testing.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes -- emotional tone is highly sensitive to context. A design-stack run focused on emotional moments (Valerie's stress, Vince's vulnerability, Susan's trust anxiety) should validate the specific copy and timing of milestone toasts.

cross_process_insights.insight: The Stays Manager is now confirmed as THE foundational architecture for Split Lease by five independent analytical processes: (1) Kahneman/Andreas identified System 1 dashboard design, (2) Kahneman/Nneka identified weekly return patterns and off-platform communication, (3) Eyal/Booking.com identified habit-forming micro-review capture within stay cycles, (4) Christensen/Innovator's Dilemma identified the overserved-to-underserved pivot from search to lifecycle management, and (5) Krug/SpareRoom now identifies bilateral active-stay management as the category's deepest undesigned territory. No other element in the entire library has this level of cross-process convergence.
cross_process_insights.implication: The Stays Manager should be treated as the product's center of gravity. Every other feature (search, listing evaluation, proposal flow, reviews) should be designed to serve the Stays Manager's weekly recurring engagement pattern. The host-side turnover checklist (rb-ui-004) is the most significant extension because it makes the Stays Manager bilateral -- a tool for both guests and hosts, not just guests.

cross_process_insights.insight: The structured commitment path from first contact to move-in is now validated by both inside-out analysis (Kahneman's uncertainty resolution, depleted user design) and outside-in analysis (Krug's street signs and breadcrumbs, SpareRoom's cliff-edge abandonment). The library now has elements covering every stage: first contact scaffolding (rb-ui-002/this run), proposal progress pipeline (guest-communicates-005/DS), anxiety-resolving status stream (guest-behaves-004/DS), pre-arrival conversation guide (rb-ui-003/Airbnb), and commitment journey breadcrumb (rb-ui-003/this run). This is the first time the full end-to-end commitment path has been covered with elements from multiple independent processes.
cross_process_insights.implication: The commitment path is ready for implementation design. The elements exist for every stage; the next step is to design the transitions between them so the breadcrumb, status stream, and scaffolded forms feel like a single coherent experience rather than separate features stitched together.

cross_process_insights.insight: The review and reputation system has achieved critical mass across three independent runs: (1) Eyal/Booking.com designed micro-review capture at natural moments and within-lease timeline visualization, (2) Krug/SpareRoom designed portable cross-lease reputation and the host turnover checklist that surfaces guest feedback, and (3) Kahneman/Nneka designed batched review prompts at reflection points. The complete architecture is: capture (micro-review pulse per stay cycle), accumulate (within-lease timeline), synthesize (end-of-lease review), and carry forward (portable reputation timeline). No single run designed this complete system; it emerged from the convergence of three independent processes.
cross_process_insights.implication: The review system should be specified as an integrated architecture, not as individual elements. The data model must support: per-stay-cycle sentiment + optional note, within-lease timeline aggregation, cross-lease reputation accumulation, and host-side visibility of guest feedback during turnovers.

cross_process_insights.insight: The people-first information architecture now has coverage across the full discovery-to-evaluation funnel: concept explainer for cold traffic (rb-ui-006/this run), schedule compatibility on search cards (guest-looks-006/DS), people-first listing hero on detail pages (rb-ui-001/this run), and people-like-you review filter on listing pages (rb-ui-002/Airbnb). This represents a complete inversion of the classified-ads paradigm that every competitor uses, validated by both the Kahneman System 1 lens (automatic pattern recognition for schedule fit) and the Krug usability lens (self-evident answers to human compatibility questions).
cross_process_insights.implication: The people-first hierarchy can be implemented as a coherent design system with consistent visual patterns: host profile components, schedule badges, compatibility tags, and contextual testimonials should share a common design language across concept explainer, search cards, listing detail, and review filters.

new_tokens_flagged.issue: All 7 new elements use Inter and DM Sans fonts with the purple production palette (#31135D, rgb(109,49,194), rgb(140,104,238)). This matches the production CSS documented in Style-guide.md but diverges from tokens.json which specifies Instrument Serif, Outfit, and IBM Plex Mono with a warm green accent (#2d5a3d). This is the known token drift documented in MEMORY.md.

Uses rgb(75, 71, 206) ('chat-purple') for progress percentage and completed checkmarks. This color appears in the Booking.com RB run elements but is not defined in tokens.json. It functions as a tertiary accent within the purple palette system.

token_compliance.recommendation: The new elements are internally consistent with each other and with the production purple palette. The token drift between tokens.json (warm green/warm neutrals) and production CSS (purple palette) remains unresolved and should be addressed at the system level -- either tokens.json should be updated to match production, or a decision should be made about which palette is canonical. All 7 new elements are safe to add to the library as-is because they follow the same conventions as the existing Booking.com and Airbnb RB elements already in the library.

discovery.source: rb-ui-006 (How Split Lease Works explainer) fills the cold-traffic concept comprehension gap. Previously no element addressed users arriving without a phone call.

evaluation.source: rb-ui-001 (People-First Listing Hero) adds listing detail page hierarchy. Combined with existing guest-looks-006 (Schedule Compatibility on cards), evaluation now has coverage at both card and detail-page levels.

onboarding.source: This run focused on SpareRoom which has no onboarding phase. The existing DS elements (works-001 through works-004) cover onboarding from the host side. Guest onboarding remains a gap.

listing_creation.source: No new elements. Existing DS elements (communicates-004, works-006) cover listing creation from the host side. This is appropriate -- SpareRoom's listing creation is not relevantly different from Split Lease's.

pricing.source: No new elements. Existing DS elements (communicates-002, works-006) address pricing display and mental model translation. This run's SpareRoom analysis validated pricing opacity as a pain point (disappoint-002) but the existing elements already address it.

proposal_mgmt.source: rb-ui-002 (Scaffolded First Contact), rb-ui-003 (Commitment Journey Breadcrumb), and rb-ui-007 (Emotional Milestone Toast at proposal acceptance). Combined with existing DS elements (communicates-005, guest-communicates-005, guest-behaves-004), this is now the most comprehensively covered phase.

active_lease.source: rb-ui-004 (Host Turnover Checklist) and rb-ui-005 (Portable Reputation Timeline). Combined with existing DS elements (guest-works-003, guest-works-004, guest-behaves-001, guest-communicates-007, guest-works-006) and Booking.com RB elements (rb-ui-001, rb-ui-002 from that run), active lease is now the deepest-covered phase from both guest and host perspectives.

retention.source: rb-ui-005 (Portable Reputation Timeline) contributes to retention by making returning users' accumulated reputation visible and valuable. Combined with existing rb-ui-004 (Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge from Airbnb run), retention has basic coverage but remains the thinnest phase.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a guest-focused design-stack using listing evaluation transcripts (Valerie, Vince, William, Susan) with a visual design book (e.g., 'The Design of Everyday Things' by Norman or 'About Face' by Cooper).
next_run_recommendations.reason: The reverse-benchmark has now produced 7 UI elements for the guest evaluation and commitment phases, but all are based on competitor analysis rather than direct user validation. A design-stack run analyzing the same transcripts through a different theoretical lens would validate or refine the information hierarchy (people-first listing), first-contact scaffolding, and emotional milestone design. The cross-process reinforcement would be exceptionally valuable.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a host-focused design-stack using Chantel, Cristina, and Nneka transcripts with an operations/service design book to design the host-side Stays Manager experience.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The rb-ui-004 (Host Turnover Checklist) is a single element addressing a deeply complex operational need. Chantel's transcript reveals extensive manual processes (inventory, cleaning protocols, access codes, building information) that a single checklist cannot fully capture. A full design-stack run would produce the complete host-side Stays Manager architecture: turnover checklists, guest communication tools, schedule management, and earnings visibility.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a reverse-benchmark analyzing Roomgo or Ideal Flatmate (SpareRoom's closest UK competitors) through a behavioral economics lens (Thaler's 'Nudge' or Ariely's 'Predictably Irrational').
next_run_recommendations.reason: This SpareRoom run revealed category-wide gaps (no commitment path, no active-stay management, no emotional design). Analyzing a second flatshare competitor would validate whether these gaps are truly category-universal or SpareRoom-specific. A behavioral economics lens would complement the Krug usability lens by adding choice architecture and nudge design to the opportunity set.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a reverse-benchmark analyzing Furnished Finder or Zeus Living (US long-term furnished rental competitors) through a trust/safety lens.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The discovery and evaluation phases remain thinly covered. Analyzing a platform that competes more directly with Split Lease's US mid-term stay market would produce elements specifically for the trust-building needed to commit to a 3-month shared living arrangement with a stranger -- the core emotional challenge every transcript reveals.
